dialog-secretroom-intro1.name: %Alfonso%
messages:
This is the inner sanctum, home to all the
knowledge we have collected about the
underpinnings of our reality.

In truth, we don't have any personal
experience with Ring Zero itself, or how
hacking actually works.
But, perhaps....

dialog-secretroom-intro2.name: %Bert%
messages: Perhaps....

If you need help, come here, read these
books.
Perhaps you will learn what you need.

dialog-secretroom-intro2.name: %Jackob%
messages:
You're the only one who can fix what's
been broken.

We will assit you if we can, but the real
work will be up to you.

dialog-secretroom-declaration-alfonso.name: %Alfonso%
messages:
I am the town's bookkeeper and chief
scholar, and can track your progress.

dialog-secretroom-declaration-bert.name: %Bert%
messages:
I know the town. The people. I know who
needs help.

dialog-secretroom-declaration-jackob1.name: %Jackob%
messages: And I....

dialog-secretroom-declaration-jackob2.name: %Jackob%
messages: Oh, dear. What was it again?

dialog-secretroom-declaration-jackob3.name: %Alfonso%
messages: You're our bookworm!

dialog-secretroom-declaration-jackob4.name: %Jackob%
messages: Ah yes!

Yes, I've read every book about hacking
ever to exist, not just what you can find
in this room!
I think. I can't quite remember.

dialog-secretroom-declaration-jackob5.name: %Alfonso%
messages:
Well, he knows more about Ring Zero than
anyone else.

Likely he'll be able to help you use the
device itself if you get stuck.

dialog-secretroom-declaration-jackob6.name: %Alfonso%
messages: Um... maybe.

dialog-secretroom-ahem.name: %Alfonso%
messages: *AHEM*

dialog-secretroom-declaration-wrapup.name: %Bert%
messages: Good luck.

dialog-secretroom-declaration-wrapup.name: %Alfonso%
messages: Yes, good luck, %PLAYER%.

Please talk to us if there's anything we
can do to help you.
We're counting on you!

dialog-secretroom-columbo1.name: %Jackob%
messages: Oh, one more thing.

dialog-secretroom-columbo2.name: %Jackob%
messages:
To enter the hex editor, simply touch your
hat with a finger.

dialog-secretroom-columbo2.name: %PLAYER%
messages: What? My hat?

But I thought it was the ring that was
magic.

dialog-secretroom-columbo2.name: %Jackob%
messages: No, not that hat.
The one on the PCB!

dialog-hackbook.name: %Town History%

dialog-hackbook-creepy1.name: %PLAYER%
messages: Um... okay, then.
No... no, wait a minute....
The Big Bad's name?

dialog-hackbook-creepy2.name: %PLAYER%
messages:
I don't think I've actually ever heard his
name before. He must have had a real name!

But everyone just calls him the Big Bad.
Why doesn't anyone use his name?

Maybe there's something I can do to this
book to get the text back to normal.

dialog-hackbook-creepy-s.name: %PLAYER%
messages: Creepy.

dialog-entities1.name: %Entities (1)%
messages:
After many years of research, we have
discovered the data structure of all
living beings, as well as miscellaneous
inanimate objects.

In all cases, hackable beings and objects
-- or 'entities' -- are driven by 32 bytes
of data, appearing as two rows of 16
bytes.

On the first row, the first twelve bytes
are the entity's true name, given in
something called "Ass Key,"

and the last four bytes are the entity's
position in the world: two bytes for its
X position, and two bytes for its
Y position.

The position of each byte within each pair
is backwards relative to what seems to us
to be logical -- and from what we
understand, a Mr. N. Dian is to blame.

dialog-entities2.name: %Entities (2)%
messages:
The second row of entity data is far more
complicated.

Changing the second pair of bytes causes
unspeakable chaos. We have learned to
leave these bytes undisturbed.

The first pair of bytes seems to affect
what the entity does when interacted with.
This pair, too, can lead to chaos if
changed.

The next five bytes apparently concern
how an entity appears, but the last of the
five affect the others in ways we are
still trying to understand.

Of the five, the first pair is more useful
to us, seeming to change the entity type,
or which among its category the entity
appears to be.

The second pair appears to do nothing the
vast majority of the time, but
occasionally it changes the entity's
appearance in odd ways --

it's almost as if certain entities exist
in a series along a parallel dimension,
and we can simply choose which dimension
is realized.

Again, all two-byte pairs are backwards
in their manifestation. We are preparing
a strongly-worded letter to Mr. N. Dian.

dialog-entities3.name: %Entities (3)%
messages:
Of the remaining seven bytes, the first
three apparently describe how the entity
is behaving.

The first byte describes the action the
entity is currently performing, while the
next describes how far along into the
action the entity has progressed.

Alas, not all entities are capable of all
actions, though some appear delightfully
animated.

The next byte first appeared only to
represent the cardinal direction the
entity is facing, but we have discovered a
secret:

If this byte is considered not as a unit
but instead as a series of 8 bits, then
the largest bit toggles a bizarre
disruption in appearance,

which we have found useful to cause great
alarm and panic among our less-enlightened
neighbors.

dialog-entities4.name: %Entities (4)%
messages: The final four bytes are quite abstract.

The first pair seems to us to bond the
entity to a physical place -- a beloved
path, a favorite chair, etc.

But the final pair... we have our
theories, but we are certain of none of
them. And so the final pair remains a
mystery.

There may yet be undiscovered secrets, and
the world may yet change around us,
rendering invalid the structure we have
already mapped.

But we will endeavor to continue our
research.

dialog-bitsbytes.name: %Bits & Bytes%
messages:
A bit is a one or a zero. But combine
eight of them, and you can describe
numbers up to 255 -- a byte.

For simplicity, it is best to think of a
byte as a pair of numbers between 0 and 15
-- or 0 and F.

Well, heck, you know how hexidecimal
works! Whatcha readin' this for?

dialog-math.name: %Math%
messages:
You know what ADDing and SUBtracting does,
but XOR is less intuitive -- unless you
are looking at the bits making up each
byte.

In which case, think of XOR as a toggle on
a single bit.

dialog-magefacts2.name: %Mage Facts%
messages: Mage Facts Magazine, issue 37.

What happens when a mage presses the
triangle button? Experts agree the answer
is "nothing."

"Why would I waste my time pressing a
button that doesn't do anything?" says
famous mage, Gorgonzola the Moist. "I have
better things to do with my life!"

94% of all mages we interviewed this week
admit they have never pressed the triangle
button even once their whole lives.

"My sensei's never used it, so I never
felt a need to try it," says one young
mage, 19, now a student at Underwand
Institute of Technology.

dialog-bookorigins.name: %Book Origins%
messages:
Meeting minutes: Smarch 32nd, year 1337
Subject: who wrote the 'Entity' books?

Alfonso: "Whoever wrote those 'Entity'
books must have had access to the real
Ring Zero."
Bert: "The Big Bad?"

Jackob: "But the Big Bad had no
accomplices, and there were clearly
multiple people doing this research."

Alfonso: "Then perhaps the Big Bad was not
the first mage to have Ring Zero. Perhaps
he will not be the last."
Bert: "Or is there more than one ring?"

dialog-redletters.name: %Red Letters%
messages:
Meeting minutes: Smarch 16th, year 1337
Subject: a rubbing taken from a
dilapidated granite plaque found deep in
the Fortran Forest:
"RED LETTERS MARK THE HACKER."

Alfonso: "Obviously this is a reference to
a calendar. Perhaps the power to hack is
granted to mages on specific days --
'red-letter' days!"

Jackob: "You mean mages can only become
hackers on national holidays? Certainly
not!"

Alfonso: "What else might it mean by 'red
letters,' then? Perhaps... when a mage
becomes a hacker, it IS a red-letter day!"

Jackob: "Or perhaps the phrase 'red
letters' is a red herring!"
